cards.back: Unlimited wants but limited resources → forces choice, opportunity cost, and trade-offs.

cards.front: Basic Economic Concepts - Production Possibilities Frontier (PPF)
cards.back: Shows maximum possible output combinations; bowed outward = increasing opportunity costs.
As price falls, quantity demanded rises (ceteris paribus). Inverse relationship.
As price rises, quantity supplied rises (ceteris paribus). Direct relationship.
Qd = Qs. No shortage or surplus. Price where market clears.

cards.front: Supply & Demand - Price Elasticity of Demand
cards.back: %∆Qd / %∆P. Elastic >1, Inelastic <1. Affects total revenue.
%∆Qd of good A / %∆P of good B. Positive = substitutes, Negative = complements.
%∆Qd / %∆Income. Positive = normal good, Negative = inferior good.
MUx/Px = MUy/Py. Spend until marginal utility per dollar is equal across goods.
As consumption increases, the additional satisfaction from each extra unit decreases.

cards.front: Consumer Choice - Income vs. Substitution Effect
cards.back: Price drop: substitution effect (buy more because relatively cheaper) + income effect (real income rises).
Shows combinations giving same satisfaction. Slope = Marginal Rate of Substitution (MRS).

cards.front: Production & Cost - Law of Diminishing Marginal Returns
cards.back: Adding more variable input to fixed inputs eventually yields smaller increases in output.
ΔTC / ΔQ. U-shaped curve due to diminishing returns.
TC/Q. U-shaped. MC intersects ATC at its minimum.
Long-run ATC falls as output expands. Specialization, bulk discounts.

cards.front: Production & Cost - Explicit vs. Implicit Costs
cards.back: Explicit: actual payments. Implicit: opportunity costs of owner's resources.

cards.front: Production & Cost - Accounting vs. Economic Profit
cards.back: Accounting = TR - explicit costs. Economic = TR - (explicit + implicit).
Many firms, identical products, price takers, free entry/exit, perfect information.
Produce where MR = MC. In PC, MR = P.
Shut down if P < AVC in short run. Exit if P < ATC in long run.
P = MC = ATC. Zero economic profit, allocatively and productively efficient.
Single seller, unique product, high barriers, price maker, no close substitutes.
MR = MC, but P > MR. Downward-sloping demand curve.
Monopoly produces less than socially optimal quantity → allocative inefficiency.
Charge different prices to different consumers based on willingness to pay. Increases profit.
Many firms, differentiated products, free entry/exit, some market power.
Zero economic profit (P = ATC), but excess capacity (not at min ATC).
Few firms, interdependent decisions, high barriers, may collude (cartel).
Individual incentives lead to non-cooperative outcome, even though cooperation benefits all.
Demand for labor (or other factors) is derived from demand for the product it helps make.
Additional revenue from hiring one more unit of labor. MRP = MP × MR.
Hire until MRP = MFC (marginal factor cost).
Single buyer of labor. Pays wage < MRP, hires fewer workers than competitive market.
Cost/benefit imposed on third parties. Negative → overproduction; Positive → underproduction.
Non-rival + non-excludable. Free-rider problem leads to underprovision by private market.
Rival + non-excludable. Tragedy of the commons → overuse/depletion.
Tax = MEC to correct negative externality. Subsidy = MEB to correct positive externality.
Price ceiling (max price) → shortage. Price floor (min price) → surplus.

cards.front: Government Intervention - Lorenz Curve & Gini Coefficient
cards.back: Lorenz shows income distribution. Gini measures inequality (0 = perfect equality, 1 = perfect inequality).
